title: 114_hr3295
content: The following sums are appropriated for fiscal year 2015 from the Treasury for the Department of Justice, specifically for state and local law enforcement assistance under the Office of Justice Programs. $140,000,000 is allocated for State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance, including funds for the Edward Byrne Memorial Justice Assistance Grant program, Drug Courts, mental health courts, programs to reduce gun crime and gang violence, and a veterans treatment courts program. $10,000,000 is allocated for Juvenile Justice Programs for community-based violence prevention initiatives, including public health approaches to reducing shootings and violence. Additionally, funding is provided for Community Oriented Policing Services programs. $30,000,000 is allocated for Community Oriented Policing Services Programs, with $15,000,000 for grants to State law enforcement agencies in high-seizure States and $15,000,000 for grants to statewide law enforcement agencies. The curr_chunk focuses on the allocation of funds for investigative purposes related to illicit activities such as precursor diversion, laboratories, methamphetamine traffickers, and heroin distribution. It includes $15,000,000 for competitive grants to statewide law enforcement agencies in States with high rates of primary treatment admissions for heroin and other opioids. The curr_chunk allocates $15,000,000 for investigative purposes to locate illicit activities related to heroin and prescription opioids in States with high treatment admissions. The curr_chunk allocates additional funding for entrepreneurial development programs and business loans at the Small Business Administration, as well as training and employment services at the Department of Labor. The curr_chunk provides additional funding for business loans program account and training and employment services. Additional funding is allocated for training and employment services, with $265,000,000 available until September 30, 2016. The Health Resources and Services Administration receives $50,000,000 for the Healthy Start Initiative, and the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration receives funding for substance abuse treatment. The Healthy Start Initiative receives an additional $50,000,000 for maternal and child health, while $10,000,000 is allocated for substance abuse treatment through drug court grants. The Department of Housing and Urban Development receives funding for the choice neighborhoods initiative. For substance abuse treatment, an additional $10,000,000 is allocated for drug court grants. The Department of Housing and Urban Development receives $170,000,000 for the Choice Neighborhoods Initiative. An additional $500,000,000 is allocated for the Community Development Fund for emergency response, recovery, infrastructure restoration, and economic revitalization in areas impacted by violence or civil unrest in 2015. Funds will be awarded to states, tribes, or local governments for authorized activities under the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974. In 2015, $500,000,000 is allocated for emergency response, recovery, and economic revitalization in areas impacted by violence or civil unrest. Funds will be awarded to distressed communities with insufficient capacity to respond to the event, based on measurable criteria like racial or income segregation and low employment levels. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will allocate funds to distressed communities with insufficient capacity to respond to events based on measurable criteria such as racial or income segregation, low employment levels, poor-performing schools, high infant mortality rates, vacant homes, and proximity to environmentally hazardous areas. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will allocate funds to distressed communities with low levels of college enrollment or employment for youth aged 17 to 25, poor-performing schools, high infant mortality rates, vacant homes, and proximity to environmentally hazardous areas. Grantees must submit a plan detailing the use of funds for long-term recovery, infrastructure, housing, and economic revitalization in the most impacted areas. The grantee must submit a plan to the Secretary detailing the proposed use of funds for long-term recovery, infrastructure, housing, and economic revitalization in distressed areas. The Secretary will specify approval criteria within 45 days of enactment, and any plan not meeting the criteria will be disapproved. The Secretary will specify approval criteria for plans within 45 days of enactment. Plans not meeting the criteria will be disapproved. Funds allocated under this heading will not affect non-emergency formula allocations. Grantees will receive training on grant management, including the use of contracts and subrecipient agreements. The Secretary will provide training on grant management for grantees, including the use of contracts and subrecipient agreements. Performance requirements and penalties must be incorporated into contracts or subrecipient agreements. The Secretary may waive or specify alternative requirements for any statute or regulation in administering the funds. The Secretary will provide training on grant management for grantees, including incorporating performance requirements and penalties into contracts or subrecipient agreements. The Secretary has the authority to waive or specify alternative requirements for statutes or regulations when administering funds, except for certain specified areas. The Secretary may waive requirements for the use of funds, except for specific areas, to provide immediate community response. Up to 30 percent of the funds can be used for technical assistance. The Secretary may use up to 30 percent of funds for technical assistance to provide immediate community response, recovery, and revitalization assistance. Up to $10,000,000 may be transferred for program office salaries and expenses. The Secretary may allocate up to 30% of funds for technical assistance in providing immediate community response, recovery, and revitalization aid. Additionally, up to $10,000,000 can be transferred for program office salaries and expenses, including information technology costs for administering and overseeing the funds. The Office of Lead Hazard Control and Healthy Homes is allocated an additional $30,000,000 for lead hazard reduction until September 30, 2016. General provisions include moving-to-work initiatives. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will extend Moving-to-Work agreements for designated agencies until fiscal year 2028, with the same terms unless mutually agreed upon changes are made. Reserve balances exceeding four months of operating expenses will remain available for agency use. The Secretary and agencies will extend agreements without statutory offset of reserve balances exceeding four months of expenses. Moving-to-Work agencies must report financial data for policy evaluation. The Act designates each amount as an emergency requirement, subject to the President's subsequent designation and transmission to Congress. The Act is also known as the "Rebuilding Urban Inner Cities Is Long Overdue Act of 2015" or the "REBUILD Act."
